body.p:
In your last number there appeared a
communication signed by the high sounding and bombastic
title of “A Reader and Preacher indeed”, who the writer of which after asking
your pardon for recomending to S. A. certain Optical Instruments,
proceeds most learnedly (as he supposes) to reccomend him (S. A.)
a few more (pairs I suppose he meant.) Spectacles to find out in a
certain Book, Chapter and Verse given, that which he the man of “deeds”
must have known, if he knew any thing about the matter, was
not there to be found, for he says, “we shall recommend him to look
“through the first Spectacles (did he mean pair?) and read the following words in
“Oracle Hayim Chap 53 Baer Hateb 16.” and then gives a hebrew quota=
tion, which he translates as follows, as being found in the place
so learnedly mentioned by him namely “A Sheliach Zibbur? has to pursua
”=ade, moralize, and to advise the Congregation in God's words”
Now in the Bear Hateb which whic was compiled by the b?
learned and pious Rabbi Judah Askanazi who was a דיין in
Lichen? in Poland in the 16 paragraph on the 53 Chapter it says
instead of it saying any thing about his pursuading-Moralizing
or adviseing them, it says that the reader who endeavors to
shew off too much, be it either with or without the consult of
the Congregation, will on sabbaths or Festivals renders himself
disgusing (מגונה)

Now what induced your corrispondent to render himself
such an in-“glorious spectacle” as he is, but attempting

to palm off such a statement, must be but known to himself,
but it would very much puzzle any honest and straightforward
man to account why one rejoicing in such high sounding
titles as he claims for himself, and one who should ought to know.
why should make such statements when either silence or truth
would have answered as well!

The Quebec man not as yet satisfied with his first
demonstration makes a second attack, and says,
“We recommend him therefer? to put on his second Spectacles and read
“in the above-mentioned books Oracle Hayim Chap 53. 25.”
which he says reads as follows viz “The Sheliach Zibbux is called
“Hazan because he has to see how he shall read”

Now, after with all due humility, having put on two pair
of Spectacles, and have examined having examined no less
than eleven editions of the Book named by him, I have
been forced to the conclusion that all that he says stands about
in the 53 Chap 25 paragraph is nothing else but a tissue of
falsehoods, for in everyone of the eleven different editions of
the “Oracle Hayen Chap 53. 26” instead of saying any thing
about why the Hazan is called this, or that, or any thing of
the Kind; it simply says “that a Hazan should not be dismissed
“from his employment, unless some blemish is found in him.”
and nothing more.

What has induced a “Reader and Preacher” thus voluntarily
to give false statements, must be a matter of some surprise,
but if all readers are as much given to such tricks as your
Provincial corrispondant, then sooner their services are

dispenced with, the better for the cause of truth of religion;
He then quotes a passage where according to his translation
it says, “A Congregation when they wish to engage a Rabbi and”
“a Reader, and are unable to pay both, shall enguage the Rabbi if he has”
“great learning and experience, but if not they shall enguage the reader,”
after which in great joy at the discovery, he then says
“Here we see that the reader has a dignity equal to that of the Rabbi.”
Now, here he appears to have already forgotten what he had wrote
but a few moments before ? for there according to his
own shewing if a proper Rabbi can be obtained for the Congrega=
=tion he shall be employed, but in case such a one cannot
be obtained, there only—and not till then, “shall they choose a reader.”
Thus according to his own shewing theory the reader is only to be
hired because a proper Rabbi cannot be obtained, making
the necessity of the reader depend on a mere chance, instead
of his “having a dignity equal to that of the Rabbi.”

Apearantly not as yet fully satisfied with the immense
amount of valuable information, that he had supplied
your numerous readers with, he says “I quote another”
and then pretends to give a translation of the 581 Chap
1st paragraph of the Oracle Hayam, which he states says
“He (the reader) shall be so pious that he can acquit or discharge every one
with his prayers.”

Now this is exactly like his former attempts to palm off that
which he knew must have known to be untrue, for instead
of that Book saying “He (the reader) shall be so pious” it
merely states that there is a custom of arising early, from
Rosh Hodesh Elul. lite? the day of Atonement to say

certain prayers (there M?) and nothing more. Following this
short paragraph of only 13 words, there is a commentary by Rabbi Myer
Israels, who lays down a great many rules about readers during
ימים נוראים, such as that they should be over thirty years of age,
that they should be married mere Hebrew but even including the
Comment. No such words as “He (the reader) should be so pious”
ever occurs, and is only to be found in the fertile imagination of your
corrispondent from Quebec.

What has induced this “Reader and Preacher indeed,” thus
to attempt to impose on the readers of the Occident,
is a matter of conjecture only, but that the Editor
should allow such statements to appear in his journal,
where the slighest glance over them, would at once have exhibited
their falsity, is truly a matter of astonishment.

Arguments to be convincing should have proberty for
their basis, for it matters but little how pleasant
a theory may appear, once known that falsehood and
not veracity is the means used, the whole whoever
comely to the eye must fall, and thus, any one
under the garb of religion using falsehood and deceit
renders himself an in-”glorious Spectacle” and finally
injurs that which he attempts to benefit.
